Posts.Content: That is so helpful, thanks. Waiting for the pathology is stressful.
Posts.Title: Post-op questions

Posts.Content: Hey all, My dad had a radical prostatectomy on 4/4/16 at Mt. Sinai with Dr. Tewari. The biopsy and pre-op MRI showed cancer in the left lobe. The pathology during surgery confirmed this in addition to cancer in the right lobe. We were surprised to learn that Dr. Tewari had to cut wider margins on the right. He did resect all the tissue until the margins were clear. Lymph nodes were reportedly negative. There was "some" nerve sparing on both sides. Does this mean that the cancer escaped the prostate and that he had "positive margins?" I'm not sure if positive margins intraoperatively are clinically significant if you end up cutting until you get negative margins. Thanks in advance for your responses. My dad is still in a lot of pain (mainly gas) from the surgery. The catheter is really bothering him (any tips there also appreciated). Finding out that the cancer was bilateral has been rough and I believe is hindering his recovery. Kate
Posts.Signature: MY DADS INFO: Age: 62 10/2014: PSA 4.8 12/2014: PSA 4.61 3/2015: PSA 4.7 9/2015: PSA 5.8 11/2015: PSA 6.0 12/2015: Biopsy  2/12 cores positive at left lobe (Gleason 6 [30%], Gleason 3+4 (80%], +perineural involvement to both positive cores) 12/2015: CT and bone scan normal 4/2016 prostatectomy with Dr. Tewari at Mt. Sinai (neg margins, no EPE, lymph nodes clear, +perineural invasion) 5/2016 still incontinent, ED present 5/2016 PSA 0.0 8/2016 PSA 0.1
Posts.Title: Post-op questions

Posts.Content: Thank you all, especially to Wilde for making me laugh with the comment about being able to "out-pee" your friends. I really love everyone's positivity on this thread. Thanks to petah for the article, as well. I also found this, which may be helpful to some: http://www.harvardprostateknowledge....-prostatectomy

Posts.Title: Help with tx options--da Vinci vs. brachytherapy?

Posts.Content: Hi all, My dad was recently dx'd with prostate cancer (please see his stats below). He is reluctant to undergo surgery due to the possible quality of life issues and also a general fear of being in the hospital, recovery, etc. If he ends up choosing surgery, he prefers to stay very local (in CT). However, I am trying to persuade him to consult with Dr. Tewari at Mt. Sinai. We recently learned that he may be a candidate for brachytherapy. I am interested to learn more about the pros and cons of this treatment. What has your experience been? Is there a particular clinic you recommend? Any insight would be greatly appreciated. Thank you all so much for contributing! Kate

Posts.Title: Help with tx options--da Vinci vs. brachytherapy?

Posts.Content: Hey all, My dad had a radical prostatectomy in April 2016 (see stats below). He is still pretty much 100% incontinent and with ED. His first post-OP PSA at 6 weeks was a 0.0. The second post-op PSA just came back with the result of 0.1. These labs were performed at the local hospital. I am wondering if this could be an issue with the local lab? He has a follow up appointment with Dr. Tewari at Mt. Sinai tomorrow. Thanks, Kate
Posts.Signature: MY DADS INFO: Age: 62 10/2014: PSA 4.8 12/2014: PSA 4.61 3/2015: PSA 4.7 9/2015: PSA 5.8 11/2015: PSA 6.0 12/2015: Biopsy  2/12 cores positive at left lobe (Gleason 6 [30%], Gleason 3+4 (80%], +perineural involvement to both positive cores) 12/2015: CT and bone scan normal 4/2016 prostatectomy with Dr. Tewari at Mt. Posts.Title: Dad's Post-op PSA at 0.1

Posts.Content: Hey guys, Thanks for responding. My parents picked up the lab reports today and confirmed the above results. I called the lab and the tests were done in-house. I'm still hoping it was a typo or lab error. If not, what a very disappointing surgical outcome -- incontinence, ED, and still not cancer-free. I'll keep you all posted. Kate
Posts.Title: Dad's Post-op PSA at 0.1

Posts.Content: Thanks for the replies. FYI--we discontinued the antihypertensives under the care of his PCP. He's now weaned off the atenolol (with normal BP), but the incontinence persists after 3 months post-op. Just wondering mainly if anyone else has regained continence after being completely incontinent 3 months (and counting) post-op? I'm just asking for words of encouragement or tips vs. medical advice.
Posts.Title: Post-surgical incontinence at 1 month

Posts.Content: Hey friends, My dad had a radical prostatectomy about 1 month ago. He is still struggling with incontinence and has only been able to urinate twice on his own during the day (at night he has better luck--anyone else with similar experiences?). My mom noted that he hadn't taken his anti-hypertensive (atenolol) on this particular day (his BP has been low since the surgery). We then recognized that this medication can actually worsen incontinence. If weaning off the atenolol doesn't prove to be helpful, what has worked for others? I know it is only a month out from his surgery, but this is obviously a huge quality of life problem. He is doing his Kegel's as directed by Dr. Tewari at Mt. Sinai. Any tips or words of encouragement would be so appreciated! Thanks all, Kate
